  • Optimization and fitting: often, you want to choose the parameters pp to maximize or minimize some objective (or â€œlossâ€ in machine learning). For example, if your ODE models some chemical reaction with unknown reaction rates or other parameters pp, you might want to fit the parameters pp to minimize the difference between u(p,t)u(p,t) and some experimentally observed concentrations.

In the latter case of optimization, you have a scalar objective function of the solution, since to minimize or maximize something you need a real number (and uu might be a vector). For example, this could take on one of the following two forms:

  1. A real-valued function g(u(p,T),T)âˆˆâ„g(u(p,T),T) \in \mathbb{R} that depends on the solution u(p,T)u(p,T) at a particular time TT. For example, if you have an experimental solution u*(t)u_{*}(t) that you are are trying to match at t=Tt=T, you might minimize g(u(p,T),T)=â€–u(p,T)âˆ’u*(T)â€–2g(u(p,T),T)=\Vert u(p,T)-u_{*}(T)\Vert^{2}.

  2. A real-valued function G(p)=âˆ«0Tg(u(p,t),t)dtG(p)=\int_{0}^{T}g(u(p,t),t)dt that depends on an average (here scaled by TT) over many times tâˆˆ(0,T)t\in(0,T) of our time-dependent gg. In the example of fitting experimental data u*(t)u_{*}(t), minimizing G(p)=âˆ«0Tâ€–u(p,t)âˆ’u*(t)â€–2dtG(p)=\int_{0}^{T}\Vert u(p,t)-u_{*}(t)\Vert^{2}dt corresponds to a least-square fit to minimize the error averaged over a time TT (e.g. the duration of your experiment).

More generally, you can give more weight to certain times than others by including a non-negative weight function w(t)w(t) in the integral: Gw(p)=âˆ«0âˆâˆ¥u(p,t)âˆ’u*(t)âˆ¥2âŸg(u(p,t),t)w(t)dt,.G_w(p)=\int_0^\infty \underbrace{\|u(p,t)-u_*(t)\|^2}_{g(u(p,t),t)} \, w(t) \, dt , . The two cases above are simply the choices w(t)=Î´(tâˆ’T)w(t) = \delta(t-T) (a Dirac delta function) and w(t)={1tâ‰¤T0otherwisew(t) = \begin{cases} 1 & t \le T \\ 0 & \text{otherwise} \end{cases} (a step function), respectively. As discussed in Problem [prob:discrete-data], you can let w(t)w(t) be a sum of delta functions to represent data at a sequence of discrete times.

In both cases, since these are scalar-valued functions, for optimization/fitting one would like to know the gradient âˆ‡pg\nabla_{p}g or âˆ‡pG\nabla_{p}G, such that, as usual, g(u(p+dp,t),t)âˆ’g(u(p,t),t)=(âˆ‡pg)Tdpg(u(p+dp,t),t)-g(u(p,t),t)=\left(\nabla_{p}g\right)^{T}dp so that Â±âˆ‡pg\pm\nabla_{p}g is the steepest ascent/descent direction for maximization/minimization of gg, respectively. It is worth emphasizing that gradients (which we only define for scalar-valued functions) have the same shape as their inputs pp, so âˆ‡pg\nabla_p g is a vector of length NN (the number of parameters) that depends on pp and tt.

These are â€œjust derivatives,â€ but probably you can see the difficulty: if we donâ€™t have a formula (explicit solution) for u(p,t)u(p,t), only some numerical software that can crank out numbers for u(p,t)u(p,t) given any parameters pp and tt, how do we apply differentiation rules to find âˆ‚u/âˆ‚p\partial u/\partial p or âˆ‡pg\nabla_{p}g? Of course, we could use finite differences as in Sec. 4â€”just crank through numerical solutions for pp and p+Î´pp+\delta p and subtract themâ€”but that will be quite slow if we want to differentiate with respect to many parameters (Nâ‰«1N\gg1), not to mention giving potentially poor accuracy. In fact, people often have huge numbers of parameters inside an ODE that they want to differentiate. Nowadays, our right-hand-side function f(u,p,t)f(u,p,t) can even contain a neural network (this is called a â€œneural ODEâ€) with thousands or millions (NN) of parameters pp, and we need all NN of these derivatives âˆ‡pg\nabla_{p}g or âˆ‡pG\nabla_{p}G to minimize the â€œlossâ€ function gg or GG. So, not only do we need to find a way to differentiate our ODE solutions (or scalar functions thereof), but these derivatives must be obtained efficiently. It turns out that there are two ways to do this, and both of them hinge on the fact that the derivative is obtained by solving another ODE:

  • Forward mode: âˆ‚uâˆ‚p\frac{\partial u}{\partial p} turns out to solve another ODE that we can integrate with the same numerical solvers for uu. This gives us all of the derivatives we could want, but the drawback is that the ODE for âˆ‚uâˆ‚p\frac{\partial u}{\partial p} is larger by a factor of NN than the original ODE for uu, so it is only practical for small NN (few parameters).

  • Reverse (â€œadjointâ€) mode: for scalar objectives, it turns out that âˆ‡pg\nabla_{p}g or âˆ‡pG\nabla_{p}G can be computed by solving a different ODE for an â€œadjointâ€ solution v(p,t)v(p,t) of the same size as uu, and then computing some simple integrals involving uu (the â€œforwardâ€ solution) and vv. This has the advantage of giving us all NN derivatives with only about twice the cost of solving for uu, regardless of the number NN of parameters. The disadvantage is that, since it turns out that vv must be integrated â€œbackwardsâ€ in time (starting from an â€œinitialâ€ condition at t=Tt=T and working back to t=0t=0) and depends on uu, it is necessary to store u(p,t)u(p,t) for all tâˆˆ[0,T]t\in[0,T] (rather than marching uu forwards in time and discarding values from previous times when they are no longer needed), which can require a vast amount of computer memory for large ODE systems integrated over long times.

We will now consider each of these approaches in more detail.

Forward sensitivity analysis of ODEs

Let us start with our ODE âˆ‚uâˆ‚t=f(u,p,t)\frac{\partial u}{\partial t}=f(u,p,t), and consider what happens to uu for a small change dpdp in pp: d(âˆ‚uâˆ‚t)âŸ=f(u,p,t)=âˆ‚âˆ‚t(du)=âˆ‚âˆ‚t(âˆ‚uâˆ‚p[dp])=âˆ‚âˆ‚t(âˆ‚uâˆ‚p)[dp]=d(f(u,p,t))=(âˆ‚fâˆ‚uâˆ‚uâˆ‚p+âˆ‚fâˆ‚p)[dp],\begin{aligned} d\underbrace{\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial t}\right)}_{=f(u,p,t)} &= \frac{\partial}{\partial t} (du) = \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \left( \frac{\partial u}{\partial p} [ dp ]\right)=\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}\right)[dp] \\ &=d(f(u,p,t)) = \left(\frac{\partial f}{\partial u}\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}+\frac{\partial f}{\partial p}\right)[dp], \end{aligned} where we have used the familiar rule (from multivariable calculus) of interchanging the order of partial derivativesâ€”a property that we will re-derive explicitly for our generalized linear-operator derivatives in our lecture on Hessians and second derivatives. Equating the right-hand sides of the two lines, we see that we have an ODE âˆ‚âˆ‚t(âˆ‚uâˆ‚p)=âˆ‚fâˆ‚uâˆ‚uâˆ‚p+âˆ‚fâˆ‚p\boxed{\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}\right)=\frac{\partial f}{\partial u}\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}+\frac{\partial f}{\partial p}} for the derivative âˆ‚uâˆ‚p\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}, whose initial condition is obtained simply by differentiating the initial condition u(p,0)=u0(p)u(p,0)=u_{0}(p) for uu: âˆ‚uâˆ‚p|t=0=âˆ‚u0âˆ‚p.\left.\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}\right|_{t=0}=\frac{\partial u_{0}}{\partial p}. We can therefore plug this into any ODE solver technique (usually numerical methods, unless we are extremely lucky and can solve this ODE analytically for a particular ff) to find âˆ‚uâˆ‚p\frac{\partial u}{\partial p} at any desired time tt. Simple, right?

The only thing that might seem a little weird here is the shape of the solution: âˆ‚uâˆ‚p\frac{\partial u}{\partial p} is a linear operator, but how can the solution of an ODE be a linear operator? It turns out that there is nothing wrong with this, but it is helpful to think about a few examples:

  • If u,pâˆˆâ„u,p\in\mathbb{R} are scalars (that is, we have a single scalar ODE with a single scalar parameter), then âˆ‚uâˆ‚p\frac{\partial u}{\partial p} is just a (time-dependent) number, and our ODE for âˆ‚uâˆ‚p\frac{\partial u}{\partial p} is an ordinary scalar ODE with an ordinary scalar initial condition.

  • If uâˆˆâ„nu\in\mathbb{R}^{n} (a â€œsystemâ€ of nn ODEs) and pâˆˆâ„p\in\mathbb{R} is a scalar, then âˆ‚uâˆ‚pâˆˆâ„n\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} is another column vector and our ODE for âˆ‚uâˆ‚p\frac{\partial u}{\partial p} is another system of nn ODEs. So, we solve two ODEs of the same size nn to obtain uu and âˆ‚uâˆ‚p\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}.

  • If uâˆˆâ„nu\in\mathbb{R}^{n} (a â€œsystemâ€ of nn ODEs) and pâˆˆâ„Np\in\mathbb{R}^{N} is a vector of NN parameters, then âˆ‚uâˆ‚pâˆˆâ„nÃ—N\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times N} is an nÃ—Nn\times N Jacobian matrix. Our ODE for âˆ‚uâˆ‚p\frac{\partial u}{\partial p} is effectivly system of nNnN ODEs for all the components of this matrix, with a matrix âˆ‚u0âˆ‚p\frac{\partial u_{0}}{\partial p} of nNnN initial conditions! Solving this â€œmatrix ODEâ€ with numerical methods poses no conceptual difficulty, but will generally require about NN times the computational work of solving for uu, simply because there are NN times as many unknowns. This could be expensive if NN is large!

This reflects our general observation of forward-mode differentiation: it is expensive when the number NN of â€œinputâ€ parameters being differentiated is large. However, forward mode is straightforward and, especially for Nâ‰²100N\lesssim100 or so, is often the first method to try when differentiating ODE solutions. Given âˆ‚uâˆ‚p\frac{\partial u}{\partial p} , one can then straightforwardly differentiate scalar objectives by the chain rule: âˆ‡pg|t=T=âˆ‚uâˆ‚pTâŸJacobianTâˆ‚gâˆ‚uTâŸvector|t=T,âˆ‡pG=âˆ«0Tâˆ‡pgdt.\begin{aligned} \left.\nabla_{p}g\right|_{t=T} & =\left.\underbrace{\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}^{T}}_{\text{Jacobian}^{T}}\underbrace{\frac{\partial g}{\partial u}^{T}}_{\text{vector}}\right|_{t=T},\\ \nabla_{p}G & =\int_{0}^{T}\nabla_{p}g\,dt. \end{aligned} The left-hand side âˆ‡pG\nabla_p G is gradient of a scalar function of NN parameters, and hence the gradient is a vector of NN components. Correspondingly, the right-hand side is an integral of an NN-component gradient âˆ‡pg\nabla_p g as well, and the integral of a vector-valued function can be viewed as simply the elementwise integral (the vector of integrals of each component).

Reverse/adjoint sensitivity analysis of ODEs

For large Nâ‰«1N\gg1 and scalar objectives gg or GG (etc.), we can in principle compute derivatives much more efficiently, with about the same cost as computing uu, by applying a â€œreverse-modeâ€ or â€œadjointâ€ approach. In other lectures, weâ€™ve obtained analogous reverse-mode methods simply by evaluating the chain rule left-to-right (outputs-to-inputs) instead of right-to-left. Conceptually, the process for ODEs is similar,13 but algebraically the derivation is rather trickier and less direct. The key thing is that, if possible, we want to avoid computing âˆ‚uâˆ‚p\frac{\partial u}{\partial p} explicitly, since this could be a prohibitively large Jacobian matrix if we have many parameters (pp is large), especially if we have many equations (uu is large).

In particular, letâ€™s start with our forward-mode sensitivity analysis, and consider the derivative Gâ€²=(âˆ‡pG)TG'=(\nabla_{p}G)^{T} where GG is the integral of a time-varying objective g(u,p,t)g(u,p,t) (which we allow to depend explicitly on pp for generality). By the chain rule, Gâ€²=âˆ«0T(âˆ‚gâˆ‚p+âˆ‚gâˆ‚uâˆ‚uâˆ‚p)dt,G'=\int_{0}^{T}\left(\frac{\partial g}{\partial p}+\frac{\partial g}{\partial u}\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}\right)dt, which involves our unwanted factor âˆ‚uâˆ‚p\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}. To get rid of this, weâ€™re going to use a â€œweird trickâ€

(much like Lagrange multipliers) of adding zero to this equation: Gâ€²=âˆ«0T[(âˆ‚gâˆ‚p+âˆ‚gâˆ‚uâˆ‚uâˆ‚p)+vT(âˆ‚âˆ‚t(âˆ‚uâˆ‚p)âˆ’âˆ‚fâˆ‚uâˆ‚uâˆ‚pâˆ’âˆ‚fâˆ‚p)âŸ=0]dtG'=\int_{0}^{T}\left[\left(\frac{\partial g}{\partial p}+\frac{\partial g}{\partial u}\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}\right)+v^{T}\underbrace{\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}\right)-\frac{\partial f}{\partial u}\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}-\frac{\partial f}{\partial p}\right)}_{=0}\right]dt for some function v(t)v(t) of the same shape as u that multiplies our â€œforward-modeâ€ equation for âˆ‚u/âˆ‚p\partial u/ \partial p. (If uâˆˆâ„nu\in\mathbb{R}^{n} then vâˆˆâ„nv\in\mathbb{R}^{n}; more generally, for other vector spaces, read vTv^{T} as an inner product with vv.) The new term vT(â‹¯)v^T (\cdots) is zero because the parenthesized expression is precisely the ODE satisfied by âˆ‚uâˆ‚p\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}, as obtained in our forward-mode analysis above, regardless of v(t)v(t). This is important because it allows us the freedom to choose v(t)v(t) to cancel the unwanted âˆ‚uâˆ‚p\frac{\partial u}{\partial p} term. In particular, if we first integrate by parts on the vTâˆ‚âˆ‚t(âˆ‚uâˆ‚p)v^{T}\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}\right) term to change it to âˆ’(âˆ‚vâˆ‚t)Tâˆ‚uâˆ‚p-\left(\frac{\partial v}{\partial t}\right)^{T}\frac{\partial u}{\partial p} plus a boundary term, then re-group the terms, we find: Gâ€²=vTâˆ‚uâˆ‚p|0T+âˆ«0T[âˆ‚gâˆ‚pâˆ’vTâˆ‚fâˆ‚p+(âˆ‚gâˆ‚uâˆ’vTâˆ‚fâˆ‚uâˆ’(âˆ‚vâˆ‚t)T)âŸwant to be zero!âˆ‚uâˆ‚p]dt.G'=\left.v^{T}\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}\right|_{0}^{T}+\int_{0}^{T}\left[\frac{\partial g}{\partial p}-v^{T}\frac{\partial f}{\partial p}+\underbrace{\left(\frac{\partial g}{\partial u}-v^{T}\frac{\partial f}{\partial u}-\left(\frac{\partial v}{\partial t}\right)^{T}\right)}_{\text{want to be zero!}}\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}\right]dt\:. If we could now set the (â‹¯)(\cdots) term to zero, then the unwanted âˆ‚uâˆ‚p\frac{\partial u}{\partial p} would vanish from the integral calculation in Gâ€²G'. We can accomplish this by choosing v(t)v(t) (which could be anything up to now) to satisfy the â€œadjointâ€ ODE: âˆ‚vâˆ‚t=(âˆ‚gâˆ‚u)Tâˆ’(âˆ‚fâˆ‚u)Tv.\boxed{\frac{\partial v}{\partial t}=\left(\frac{\partial g}{\partial u}\right)^{T} - \left(\frac{\partial f}{\partial u}\right)^{T}v}. What initial condition should we choose for v(t)v(t)? Well, we can use this choice to get rid of the boundary term we obtained above from integration by parts: vTâˆ‚uâˆ‚p|0T=v(T)Tâˆ‚uâˆ‚p|TâŸunknownâˆ’v(0)Tâˆ‚u0âˆ‚pâŸknown.\left.v^{T}\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}\right|_{0}^{T}=v(T)^{T}\underbrace{\left.\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}\right|_{T}}_{\text{unknown}}-v(0)^{T}\underbrace{\frac{\partial u_{0}}{\partial p}}_{\text{known}}. Here, the unknown âˆ‚uâˆ‚p|T\left.\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}\right|_{T} term is a problemâ€”to compute that, we would be forced to go back to integrating our big âˆ‚uâˆ‚p\frac{\partial u}{\partial p} ODE from forward mode. The other term is okay: since the initial condition u0u_{0} is always given, we should know its dependence on pp explicitly (and we will simply have âˆ‚u0âˆ‚p=0\frac{\partial u_{0}}{\partial p}=0 in the common case where the initial conditions donâ€™t depend on pp). To eliminate the âˆ‚uâˆ‚p|T\left.\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}\right|_{T} term, therefore, we make the choice v(T)=0.\boxed{v(T)=0}. Instead of an initial condition, our adjoint ODE has a final condition. Thatâ€™s no problem for a numerical solver: it just means that the adjoint ODE is integrated backwards in time, starting from t=Tt=T and working down to t=0t=0. Once we have solved the adjoint ODE for v(t)v(t), we can plug it into our equation for Gâ€²G' to obtain our gradient by a simple integral: âˆ‡pG=(Gâ€²)T=âˆ’(âˆ‚u0âˆ‚p)Tv(0)+âˆ«0T[(âˆ‚gâˆ‚p)Tâˆ’(âˆ‚fâˆ‚p)Tv]dt.\nabla_{p}G=\left(G'\right)^{T}=-\left(\frac{\partial u_{0}}{\partial p}\right)^{T}v(0)+\int_{0}^{T}\left[\left(\frac{\partial g}{\partial p}\right)^{T}-\left(\frac{\partial f}{\partial p}\right)^{T}v\right]dt\:. (If you want to be fancy, you can compute this âˆ«0T\int_{0}^{T} simultaneously with vv itself, by augmenting the adjoint ODE with an additional set of unknowns and equations representing the Gâ€²G' integrand. But thatâ€™s mainly just a computational convenience and doesnâ€™t change anything fundamental about the process.)

The only remaining annoyance is that the adjoint ODE depends on u(p,t)u(p,t) for all tâˆˆ[0,T]t\in[0,T]. Normally, if we are solving the â€œforwardâ€ ODE for u(p,t)u(p,t) numerically, we can â€œmarchâ€ the solution uu forwards in time and only store the solution at a few of the most recent timesteps. Since the adjoint ODE starts at t=Tt=T, however, we can only start integrating vv after we have completed the calculation of uu. This requires us to save essentially all of our previously computed u(p,t)u(p,t) values, so that we can evaluate uu at arbitrary times tâˆˆ[0,T]t\in[0,T] during the integration of vv (and Gâ€²G'). This can require a lot of computer memory if uu is large (e.g. it could represent millions of grid points from a spatially discretized PDE, such as in a heat-diffusion problem) and many timesteps tt were required. To ameliorate this challenge, a variety of strategies have been employed, typically centered around â€œcheckpointingâ€ techniques in which uu is only saved at a subset of times tt, and its value at other times is obtained during the vv integration by re-computing uu as needed (numerically integrating the ODE starting at the closest â€œcheckpointâ€ time). A detailed discussion of such techniques lies outside the scope of these notes, however.

Example

Let us illustrate the above techniques with a simple example. Suppose that we are integrating the scalar ODE âˆ‚uâˆ‚t=f(u,p,t)=p1+p2u+p3u2=pT(1uu2)\frac{\partial u}{\partial t}=f(u,p,t)=p_{1}+p_{2}u+p_{3}u^{2}=p^{T}\left(\begin{array}{c} 1\\ u\\ u^{2} \end{array}\right) for an initial condition u(p,0)=u0=0u(p,0)=u_{0}=0 and three parameters pâˆˆâ„3p \in \mathbb{R}^3. (This is probably simple enough to solve in closed form, but we wonâ€™t bother with that here.) We will also consider the scalar function G(p)=âˆ«0T[u(p,t)âˆ’u*(t)]2âŸg(u,p,t)dtG(p)=\int_{0}^{T}\underbrace{\left[u(p,t)-u_{*}(t)\right]^{2}}_{g(u,p,t)}dt that (for example) we may want to minimize for some given u*(t)u_{*}(t) (e.g. experimental data or some given formula like u*=t3u_{*}=t^{3}), so we are hoping to compute âˆ‡pG\nabla_{p}G.

Forward mode

The Jacobian matrix âˆ‚uâˆ‚p=(âˆ‚uâˆ‚p1âˆ‚uâˆ‚p2âˆ‚uâˆ‚p3)\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}=\left(\begin{array}{ccc} \frac{\partial u}{\partial p_{1}} & \frac{\partial u}{\partial p_{2}} & \frac{\partial u}{\partial p_{3}}\end{array}\right) is simply a row vector, and satisfies our â€œforward-modeâ€ ODE: âˆ‚âˆ‚t(âˆ‚uâˆ‚p)=âˆ‚fâˆ‚uâˆ‚uâˆ‚p+âˆ‚fâˆ‚p=(p2+2p3u)âˆ‚uâˆ‚p+(1uu2)\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}\right)=\frac{\partial f}{\partial u}\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}+\frac{\partial f}{\partial p}=\left(p_{2}+2p_{3}u\right)\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}+\left(\begin{array}{ccc} 1 & u & u^{2}\end{array}\right) for the initial condition âˆ‚uâˆ‚p|t=0=âˆ‚u0âˆ‚p=0\left.\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}\right|_{t=0}=\frac{\partial u_{0}}{\partial p}=0. This is an inhomogeneous system of three coupled linear ODEs, which might look more conventional if we simply transpose both sides: âˆ‚âˆ‚t(âˆ‚uâˆ‚p1âˆ‚uâˆ‚p2âˆ‚uâˆ‚p3)âŸ(âˆ‚u/âˆ‚p)T=(p2+2p3u)(âˆ‚uâˆ‚p1âˆ‚uâˆ‚p2âˆ‚uâˆ‚p3)+(1uu2).\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\underbrace{\left(\begin{array}{c} \frac{\partial u}{\partial p_{1}}\\ \frac{\partial u}{\partial p_{2}}\\ \frac{\partial u}{\partial p_{3}} \end{array}\right)}_{(\partial u/\partial p)^{T}}=\left(p_{2}+2p_{3}u\right)\left(\begin{array}{c} \frac{\partial u}{\partial p_{1}}\\ \frac{\partial u}{\partial p_{2}}\\ \frac{\partial u}{\partial p_{3}} \end{array}\right)+\left(\begin{array}{c} 1\\ u\\ u^{2} \end{array}\right). The fact that this depends on our â€œforwardâ€ solution u(p,t)u(p,t) makes it not so easy to solve by hand, but a computer can solve it numerically with no difficulty. On a computer, we would probably solve for uu and âˆ‚u/âˆ‚p\partial u/ \partial psimultaneously by combining the two ODEs into a single ODE with 4 components: âˆ‚âˆ‚t(u(âˆ‚u/âˆ‚p)T)=(p1+p2u+p3u2(p2+2p3u)(âˆ‚u/âˆ‚p)T+(1uu2)).\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\left(\begin{array}{c} u \\ (\partial u/\partial p)^{T} \end{array}\right) = \left(\begin{array}{c} p_{1}+p_{2}u+p_{3}u^{2} \\ \left(p_{2}+2p_{3}u\right) (\partial u/\partial p)^{T} +\left(\begin{array}{c} 1\\ u\\ u^{2} \end{array}\right) \end{array}\right). Given âˆ‚u/âˆ‚p\partial u/\partial p, we can then plug this into the chain rule for GG: âˆ‡pG=2âˆ«0T[u(p,t)âˆ’u*(t)]âˆ‚uâˆ‚pTdt\nabla_{p}G=2\int_{0}^{T}\left[u(p,t)-u_{*}(t)\right]\frac{\partial u}{\partial p}^{T}\,dt (again, an integral that a computer could evaluate numerically).

Reverse mode

In reverse mode, we have an adjoint solution v(t)âˆˆâ„v(t)\in\mathbb{R} (the same shape as uu) which solves our adjoint equation âˆ‚vdt=(âˆ‚gâˆ‚u)Tâˆ’(âˆ‚fâˆ‚u)Tv=2[u(p,t)âˆ’u*(t)]âˆ’(p2+2p3u)v\frac{\partial v}{dt}=\left(\frac{\partial g}{\partial u}\right)^{T} -\left(\frac{\partial f}{\partial u}\right)^{T}v =2\left[u(p,t)-u_{*}(t)\right] - \left(p_{2}+2p_{3}u\right)v with a final condition v(T)=0.v(T)=0. Again, a computer can solve this numerically without difficulty (given the numerical â€œforwardâ€ solution uu) to find v(t)v(t) for tâˆˆ[0,T]t\in[0,T]. Finally, our gradient is the integrated product: âˆ‡pG=âˆ’âˆ«0T(1uu2)vdt.\nabla_{p}G = -\int_{0}^{T} \left( \begin{array}{c} 1 \\ u \\ u^{2} \end{array} \right) v\,dt\:.

Another useful exercise is to consider a GG that takes the form of a summation:

Suppose that G(p)G(p) takes the form of a sum of KK terms: G(p)=âˆ‘k=1Kgk(p,u(p,tk))G(p) = \sum_{k=1}^{K} g_k(p,u(p,t_k)) for times tkâˆˆ(0,T)t_k \in (0, T) and functions gk(p,u)g_k(p,u). For example, this could arise in least-square fitting of experimental data u*(tk)u_*(t_k) at KK discrete times, with gk(u(p,tk))=â€–u*(tk)âˆ’u(p,tk)â€–2g_k(u(p,t_k)) = \Vert u_*(t_k) -u(p,t_k)\Vert^2 measuring the squared difference between u(p,tk)u(p,t_k) and the measured data at time tkt_k.

  1. Show that such a G(p)G(p) can be expressed as a special case of our formulation in this chapter, by defining our function g(u,t)g(u,t) using a sum of Dirac delta functions Î´(tâˆ’tk)\delta(t - t_k).

  2. Explain how this affects the adjoint solution v(t)v(t): in particular, how the introduction of delta-function terms on the right-hand side of dv/dtdv/dt causes v(t)v(t) to have a sequence of discontinuous jumps. (In several popular numerical ODE solvers, such discontinuities can be incorporated via discrete-time â€œcallbacksâ€.)

  3. Explain how these delta functions may also introduce a summation into the computation of âˆ‡pG\nabla_p G, but only if gkg_k depends explicitly on pp (not just via uu).

Further reading

A classic reference on reverse/adjoint differentiation of ODEs (and generalizations thereof), using notation similar to that used today (except that the adjoint solution vv is denoted Î»(t)\lambda(t), in an homage to Lagrange multipliers), is Cao et al. (2003) (https://doi.org/10.1137/S1064827501380630), and a more recent review article is Sapienza et al. (2024) (https://arxiv.org/abs/2406.09699). See also the SciMLSensitivity.jl package (https://github.com/SciML/SciMLSensitivity.jl) for sensitivity analysis with Chris Rackauckasâ€™s amazing DifferentialEquations.jl software suite for numerical solution of ODEs in Julia. There is a nice 2021 YouTube lecture on adjoint sensitivity of ODEs (https://youtu.be/k6s2G5MZv-I), again using a similar notation. A discrete version of this process arises for recurrence relations, in which case one obtains a reverse-order â€œadjointâ€ recurrence relation as described in MIT course notes by S. G. Johnson (https://math.mit.edu/~stevenj/18.336/recurrence2.pdf).

The differentiation methods in this chapter (e.g. for âˆ‚u/âˆ‚p\partial u/\partial p or âˆ‡pG\nabla_p G) are derived assuming that the ODEs are solved exactly: given the exact ODE for uu, we derived an exact ODE for the derivative. On a computer, you will solve these forward and adjoint ODEs approximately, and in consequence the resulting derivatives will only be approximately correct (to the tolerance specified by your ODE solver). This is known as a differentiate-then-discretize approach, which has the advantage of simplicity (it is independent of the numerical solution scheme) at the expense of slight inaccuracy (your approximate derivative will not exactly predict the first-order change in your approximate solution uu). The alternative is a discretize-then-differentiate approach, in which you first approximate (â€œdiscretizeâ€) your ODE into a discrete-time recurrence formula, and then exactly differentiate the recurrence. This has the advantage of exactly differentiating your approximate solution, at the expense of complexity (the derivation is specific to your discretization scheme). Various authors discuss these tradeoffs and their implications, e.g. in chapter 4 of M. D. Gunzburgerâ€™s Perspectives in Flow Control and Optimization (2002) or in papers like Jensen et al. (2014).

Calculus of Variations

In this lecture, we will apply our derivative machinery to a new type of input: neither scalars, nor column vectors, nor matrices, but rather the inputs will be functions u(x)u(x), which form a perfectly good vector space (and can even have norms and inner products).14 It turns out that there are lots of amazing applications for differentiating with respect to functions, and the resulting techniques are sometimes called the â€œcalculus of variationsâ€ and/or â€œFrechÃ©tâ€ derivatives.

Functionals: Mapping functions to scalars

For example, consider functions u(x)u(x) that map $x\in [0,1] \to u(x) \in \R$. We may then define the function ff: f(u)=âˆ«01sin(u(x))dx.f(u) = \int_0^1 \sin (u(x)) \,\mathrm{d} x. Such a function, mapping an input function uu to an output number, is sometimes called a â€œfunctional.â€ What is fâ€²f' or âˆ‡f\nabla f in this case?

Recall that, given any function ff, we always define the derivative as a linear operator fâ€²(u)f'(u) via the equation: df=f(u+du)âˆ’f(u)=fâ€²(u)[du],df = f (u + du ) - f(u) = f'(u) [du] \, , where now dudu denotes an arbitrary â€œsmall-valuedâ€ function du(x)du(x) that represents a small change in u(x)u(x), as depicted in Fig. 7 for the analogous case of a non-infinitesimal Î´u(x)\delta u(x). Here, we may compute this via linearization of the integrand: df=f(u+du)âˆ’f(u)=âˆ«01sin(u(x)+du(x))âˆ’sin(u(x))dx=âˆ«01cos(u(x))du(x)dx=fâ€²(u)[du],\begin{aligned} df &= f(u+ du) - f(u) \\ &=\int_0^1 \sin (u(x) + du(x)) - \sin (u(x)) \, dx \\ &= \int_0^1 \cos (u(x)) \, du(x) \, dx = f'(u) [du] \, , \end{aligned} where in the last step we took du(x)du(x) to be arbitrarily small15 so that we could linearize sin(u+du)\sin(u + du) to first-order in du(x)du(x). Thatâ€™s it, we have our derivative fâ€²(u)f'(u) as a perfectly good linear operation acting on dudu!

Inner products of functions

In order to define a gradient âˆ‡f\nabla f when studying such â€œfunctionalsâ€ (maps from functions to $\R$), it is natural to ask if there is an inner product on the input space. In fact, there are perfectly good ways to define inner products of functions! Given functions u(x),v(x)u(x), v(x) defined on xâˆˆ[0,1]x\in [0,1], we could define a â€œEuclideanâ€ inner product: âŸ¨u,vâŸ©=âˆ«01u(x)v(x)dx.\langle u, v \rangle = \int_0^1 u(x) v(x) \,\mathrm dx. Notice that this implies â€–uâ€–:=âŸ¨u,uâŸ©=âˆ«01u(x)2dx.\lVert u \rVert := \sqrt{\langle u, u \rangle} = \sqrt{\int_0^1 u(x)^2 dx} \, .

Recall that the gradient âˆ‡f\nabla f is defined as whatever we take the inner product of dudu with to obtain dfdf. Therefore, we obtain the gradient as follows: df=fâ€²(u)[du]=âˆ«01cos(u(x))du(x)dx=âŸ¨âˆ‡f,duâŸ©âŸ¹âˆ‡f=cos(u(x)).df = f'(u)[du] = \int_0^1 \cos(u(x)) \,du(x)\, dx = \langle \nabla f, du \rangle \implies \nabla f = \cos (u(x)) \, . The two infinitesimals dudu and dxdx may seem a bit disconcerting, but if this is confusing you can just think of the du(x)du(x) as a small non-infinitesimal function Î´u(x)\delta u(x) (as in Fig. 7) for which we are dropping higher-order terms.

The gradient âˆ‡f\nabla f is just another function, cos(u(x))\cos(u(x))! As usual, âˆ‡f\nabla f has the same â€œshapeâ€ as uu.

Remark. It might be instructive here to compare the gradient of an integral, above, with a discretized version where the integral is replaced by a sum. If we have f(u)=âˆ‘k=1nsin(uk)Î”xf(u) = \sum_{k=1}^n \sin(u_k) \Delta x \, where Î”x=1/n\Delta x = 1/n, for a vector uâˆˆâ„nu \in \mathbb{R}^n, related to our previous u(x)u(x) by uk=u(kÎ”x)u_k = u(k\Delta x), which can be thought of as a â€œrectangle ruleâ€ (or Riemann sum, or Euler) approximation for the integral. Then, âˆ‡uf=(cos(u1)cos(u2)â‹®)Î”x.\nabla_u f = \begin{pmatrix} \cos(u_1) \\ \cos(u_2) \\ \vdots \end{pmatrix} \Delta x \, . Why does this discrete version have a Î”x\Delta x multiplying the gradient, whereas our continuous version did not? The reason is that in the continuous version we effectively included the dxdx in the definition of the inner product âŸ¨u,vâŸ©\langle u, v \rangle (which was an integral). In discrete case, the ordinary inner product (used to define the conventional gradient) is just a sum without a Î”x\Delta x. However, if we define a weighted discrete inner product âŸ¨u,vâŸ©=âˆ‘k=1nukvkÎ”x\langle u, v \rangle = \sum_{k=1}^n u_k v_k \Delta x, then, according to Sec. 5, this changes the definition of the gradient, and in fact will remove the Î”x\Delta x term to correspond to the continuous version.

Example: Minimizing arc length

We now consider a more tricky example with an intuitive geometric interpretation.

Let uu be a differentiable function on [0,1][0,1] and consider the functional f(u)=âˆ«011+uâ€²(x)2dx.f(u) = \int_0^1 \sqrt{1+ u'(x)^2}\,dx. Solve for âˆ‡f\nabla f when u(0)=u(1)=0.u(0) = u(1) = 0.

Geometrically, you learned in first-year calculus that this is simply the length of the curve u(x)u(x) from x=0x=0 to x=1x=1. To differentiate this, first notice that ordinary single-variable calculus gives us the linearization d(1+v2)=1+(v+dv)2âˆ’1+v2=(1+v2)â€²dv=v1+v2dv.d\left( \sqrt{1 + v^2} \right) = \sqrt{1+ (v + dv)^2} - \sqrt{1 + v^2} = \left( \sqrt{1 + v^2} \right)' dv = \frac{v}{\sqrt{1+ v^2}} dv \, . Therefore, df=f(u+du)âˆ’f(u)=âˆ«01(1+(u+du)â€²2âˆ’1+uâ€²2)dx=âˆ«01uâ€²1+uâ€²2duâ€²dx.\begin{aligned} df &= f(u+ du) - f(u) \\ &= \int_0^1 \left( \sqrt{1 + (u+du)'^2} - \sqrt{1 + u'^2} \right) dx \\ &= \int_0^1 \frac{u'}{\sqrt{1 + u'^2}} \, du' dx. \end{aligned} However, this is a linear operator on duâ€²du' and not (directly) on dudu. Abstractly, this is fine, because duâ€²du' is itself a linear operation on dudu, so we have fâ€²(u)[du]f'(u)[du] as the composition of two linear operations. However, it is more revealing to rewrite it explicitly in terms of dudu, for example in order to define âˆ‡f\nabla f. To accomplish this, we can apply integration by parts to obtain fâ€²(u)[du]=âˆ«01uâ€²1+uâ€²2duâ€²dx=uâ€²1+uâ€²2du|01âˆ’âˆ«01(uâ€²1+uâ€²2)â€²dudx.f'(u) [du] = \int_0^1 \frac{u'}{\sqrt{1 + u'^2}} \, du' dx = \left. \frac{u'}{\sqrt{1 + u'^2}} du \right|_0^1 - \int_0^1 \left(\frac{u'}{\sqrt{1 + u'^2}}\right)' \, du \, dx \, .

Notice that up until now we did not need utilize the â€œboundary conditionsâ€ u(0)=u(1)=0u(0) = u(1) = 0 for this calculation. However, if we want to restrict ourselves to such functions u(x)u(x), then our perturbation dudu cannot change the endpoint values, i.e. we must have du(0)=du(1)=0du(0) = du(1) = 0. (Geometrically, suppose that we want to find the uu that minimizes arc length between (0,0)(0,0) and (1,0)(1,0), so that we need to fix the endpoints.) This implies that the boundary term in the above equation is zero. Hence, we have that df=âˆ’âˆ«01(uâ€²1+uâ€²2)â€²âŸâˆ‡fdudx=âŸ¨âˆ‡f,duâŸ©.df = -\int_0^1 \underbrace{\left(\frac{u'}{\sqrt{1 + u'^2}}\right)'}_{\nabla f} \, du \, dx = \langle \nabla f , du \rangle \, .

Furthermore, note that the uu that minimizes the functional ff has the property that âˆ‡f|u=0\left. \nabla f \right|_u = 0. Therefore, for a uu that minimizes the functional ff (the shortest curve), we must have the following result: 0=âˆ‡f=âˆ’(uâ€²1+uâ€²2)â€²=âˆ’uâ€³1+uâ€²2âˆ’uâ€²uâ€³uâ€²1+uâ€²21+uâ€²2=âˆ’uâ€³(1+uâ€²2)âˆ’uâ€³uâ€²2(1+uâ€²2)3/2=âˆ’uâ€³(1+uâ€²2)3/2.\begin{aligned} 0 = \nabla f &= -\left(\frac{u'}{\sqrt{1 + u'^2}}\right)' \\ &= -\frac{u'' \sqrt{1 + u'^2} - u' \frac{u'' u '}{\sqrt{1 + u'^2}}}{ 1 + u'^2} \\ &= -\frac{u'' ( 1 + u'^2) - u'' u'^2}{(1 + u'^2)^{3/2}} \\ &= -\frac{u''}{( 1+ u'^2)^{3/2}}. \end{aligned} Hence, âˆ‡f=0âŸ¹uâ€³(x)=0âŸ¹u(x)=ax+b\nabla f = 0 \implies u''(x) = 0 \implies u(x) = ax + b for constants a,ba,b; and for these boundary conditions a=b=0a=b=0. In other words, uu is the horizontal straight line segment!

Thus, we have recovered the familiar result that straight line segments in $\R^2$ are the shortest curves between two points!

Remark. Notice that the expression uâ€³(1+uâ€²2)3/2\frac{u''}{(1+ u'^2)^{3/2}} is the formula from multivariable calculus for the curvature of the curve defined by y=u(x)y= u(x). It is not a coincidence that the gradient of arc length is the (negative) curvature, and the minimum arc length occurs for zero gradient = zero curvature.

Eulerâ€“Lagrange equations

This style of calculation is part of the subject known as the calculus of variations. Of course, the final answer in the example above (a straight line) may have been obvious, but a similar approach can be applied to many more interesting problems. We can generalize the approach as follows:

Let f(u)=âˆ«abF(u,uâ€²,x)dxf(u) = \int_a^b F(u, u', x) \, dx where uu is a differentiable function on [a,b][a,b]. Suppose the endpoints of uu are fixed (i.e. its values at x=ax=a and x=bx=b are constants). Let us calculate dfdf and âˆ‡f\nabla f.

We find: df=f(u+du)âˆ’f(u)=âˆ«ab(âˆ‚Fâˆ‚udu+âˆ‚Fâˆ‚uâ€²duâ€²)dx=âˆ‚Fâˆ‚uâ€²du|abâŸ=0+âˆ«ab(âˆ‚Fâˆ‚uâˆ’(âˆ‚Fâˆ‚uâ€²)â€²)dudx,\begin{aligned} df &= f(u + du) - f(u) \\ &= \int_a^b \left(\frac{\partial F}{\partial u} du + \frac{\partial F}{\partial u'} du' \right) dx \\ &= \underbrace{\frac{\partial F}{\partial u'} du \bigr|_a^b}_{= 0} + \int_a^b \left( \frac{\partial F}{\partial u} - \left(\frac{\partial F}{\partial u'}\right)'\right) \, du \, dx \, , \end{aligned} where we used the fact that du=0du = 0 at aa or bb if the endpoints u(a)u(a) and u(b)u(b) are fixed. Hence, âˆ‡f=âˆ‚Fâˆ‚uâˆ’(âˆ‚Fâˆ‚uâ€²)â€²,\nabla f = \frac{\partial F}{\partial u} - \left(\frac{\partial F}{\partial u'}\right)', which equals zero at extremum. Notice that âˆ‡f=0\nabla f = 0 yields a second-order differential equation in uu, known as the Eulerâ€“Lagrange equations!

Remark. The notation âˆ‚F/âˆ‚uâ€²\partial F / \partial u' is a notoriously confusing aspect of the calculus of variationsâ€”what does it mean to take the derivative â€œwith respect to uâ€²u'â€ while holding uu fixed? A more explicit, albeit more verbose, way of expressing this is to think of F(u,v,x)F(u,v,x) as a function of three unrelated arguments, for which we only substitute v=uâ€²v=u' after differentiating with respect to the second argument vv: âˆ‚Fâˆ‚uâ€²=âˆ‚Fâˆ‚v|v=uâ€².\frac{\partial F}{\partial u'} = \left. \frac{\partial F}{\partial v} \right|_{v=u'} \, .

There are many wonderful applications of this idea. For example, search online for information about the â€œbrachistochrone problemâ€ (animated here) and/or the â€œprinciple of least actionâ€. Another example is a catenary curve, which minimizes the potential energy of a hanging cable. A classic textbook on the topic is Calculus of Variations by Gelfand and Fomin.

Derivatives of Random Functions

These notes are from a guest lecture by Gaurav Arya in IAP 2023.

Introduction

In this class, weâ€™ve learned how to take derivatives of all sorts of crazy functions. Recall one of our first examples: f(A)=A2,f(A) = A^2, where AA is a matrix. To differentiate this function, we had to go back to the drawing board, and ask:

If we perturb the input slightly, how does the output change?

To this end, we wrote down something like: Î´f=(A+Î´A)2âˆ’A2=A(Î´A)+(Î´A)A+(Î´A)2âŸneglected.\delta f = (A+\delta A)^2 - A^2 = A (\delta A) + (\delta A) A + \underbrace{(\delta A)^2}_{\text{neglected}}. We called Î´f\delta f and Î´A\delta A differentials in the limit where Î´A\delta A became arbitrarily small. We then had to ask:

What terms in the differential can we neglect?

We decided that (Î´A)2(\delta A)^2 should be neglected, justifying this by the fact that (Î´A)2(\delta A)^2 is â€œhigher-orderâ€. We were left with the derivative operator Î´Aâ†¦A(Î´A)+(Î´A)A\delta A \mapsto A(\delta A) + (\delta A) A: the best possible linear approximation to ff in a neighbourhood of AA. At a high level, the main challenge here was dealing with complicated input and output spaces: ff was matrix-valued, and also matrix-accepting. We had to ask ourselves: in this case, what should the notion of a derivative even mean?

In this lecture, we will face a similar challenge, but with an even weirder type of function. This time, the output of our function will be random. Now, we need to revisit the same questions. If the output is random, how can we describe its response to a change in the input? And how can we form a useful notion of derivative?

Stochastic programs

More precisely, we will consider random, or stochastic, functions XX with real input pâˆˆâ„p \in \mathbb{R} and real-valued random-variable output. As a map, we can write XX as pâ†¦X(p),p \mapsto X(p), where X(p)X(p) is a random variable. (To keep things simple, weâ€™ll take pâˆˆâ„p \in \mathbb{R} and X(p)âˆˆâ„X(p) \in \mathbb{R} in this chapter, though of course they could be generalized to other vector spaces as in the other chapters. For now, the randomness is complicated enough to deal with.)

The idea is that we can only sample from X(p)X(p), according to some distribution of numbers with probabilities that depend upon pp. One simple example would be sampling real numbers uniformly (equal probabilities) from the interval [0,p][0,p]. As a more complicated example, suppose X(p)X(p) follows the exponential distribution with scale pp, corresponding to randomly sampled real numbers xâ‰¥0x \ge 0 whose probability decreases proportional to eâˆ’x/pe^{-x/p}. This can be denoted X(p)âˆ¼Exp(p)X(p) \sim \operatorname{Exp}(p), and implemented in Julia by:

julia> using Distributions

julia> sample_X(p) = rand(Exponential(p))
sample_X (generic function with 1 method)

We can take a few samples:

julia> sample_X(10.0)
1.7849785709142214

julia> sample_X(10.0)
4.435847397169775

julia> sample_X(10.0)
0.6823343897949835

julia> mean(sample_X(10.0) for i = 1:10^9) # mean = p
9.999930348291866

If our program gives a different output each time, what could a useful notion of derivative be? Before we try to answer this, letâ€™s ask why we might want to take a derivative. The answer is that we may be very interested in statistical properties of random functions, i.e. values that can be expressed using averages. Even if a function is stochastic, its average (â€œexpected valueâ€), assuming the average exists, can be a deterministic function of its parameters that has a conventional derivative.

So, why not take the average first, and then take the ordinary derivative of this average? This simple approach works for very basic stochastic functions (e.g. the exponential distribution above has expected value pp, with derivative 11), but runs into practical difficulties for more complicated distributions (as are commonly implemented by large computer programs working with random numbers).

Remark. It is often much easier to produce an â€œunbiased estimateâ€ X(p)X(p) of a statistical quantity than to compute it exactly. (Here, an unbiased estimate means that X(p)X(p) averages out to our statistical quantity of interest.)

For example, in deep learning, the â€œvariational autoencoderâ€ (VAE) is a very common architecture that is inherently stochastic. It is easy to get a stochastic unbiased estimate of the loss function by running a random simulation X(p)X(p): the loss function L(p)L(p) is then the â€œaverageâ€ value of X(p)X(p), denoted by the expected value $\EE[X(p)]$. However, computing the loss L(p)L(p) exactly would require integrating over all possible outcomes, which usually is impractical. Now, to train the VAE, we also need to differentiate L(p)L(p), i.e. differentiate $\EE[X(p)]$ with respect to pp!

Perhaps more intuitive examples can be found in the physical sciences, where randomness may be baked into your model of a physical process. In this case, itâ€™s hard to get around the fact that you need to deal with stochasticity! For example, you may have two particles that interact with an average rate of rr. But in reality, the times when these interactions actually occur follow a stochastic process. (In fact, the time until the first interaction might be exponentially distributed, with scale 1/r1/r.) And if you want to (e.g.) fit the parameters of your stochastic model to real-world data, itâ€™s once again very useful to have derivatives.

If we canâ€™t compute our statistical quantity of interest exactly, it seems unreasonable to assume we can compute its derivative exactly. However, we could hope to stochastically estimate its derivative. That is, if X(p)X(p) represents the full program that produces an unbiased estimate of our statistical quantity, hereâ€™s one property weâ€™d definitely like our notion of derivative to have: we should be able to construct from it an unbiased gradient estimator16 Xâ€²(p)X'(p) satisfying $$\EE[X'(p)] = \EE[X(p)]' = \frac{\partial \EE[X(p)]}{\partial p}.$$ Of course, there are infinitely many such estimators. For example, given any estimator Xâ€²(p)X'(p) we can add any other random variable that has zero average without changing the expectation value. But in practice there are two additional considerations: (1) we want Xâ€²(p)X'(p) to be easy to compute/sample (about as easy as X(p)X(p)), and (2) we want the variance (the â€œspreadâ€) of Xâ€²(p)X'(p) to be small enough that we donâ€™t need too many samples to estimate its average accurately (hopefully no worse than estimating $\EE[X(p)]$).

Stochastic differentials and the reparameterization trick

Letâ€™s begin by answering our first question (Question [question:perturb]): how does X(p)X(p) respond to a change in pp? Let us consider a specific pp and write down a stochastic differential, taking a small but non-infinitesimal Î´p\delta p to avoid thinking about infinitesimals for now: Î´X(p)=X(p+Î´p)âˆ’X(p),\delta X(p) = X(p + \delta p) - X(p), where Î´p\delta p represents an arbitrary small change in pp. What sort of object is Î´X(p)\delta X(p)?

Since weâ€™re subtracting two random variables, it ought to itself be a random variable. However, Î´X(p)\delta X(p) is still not fully specified! We have only specified the marginal distributions of X(p)X(p) and X(p+Î´p)X(p+\delta p): to be able to subtract the two, we need to know their joint distribution.

One possibility is to treat X(p)X(p) and X(p+Î´p)X(p + \delta p) as independent. This means that Î´X(p)\delta X(p) would be constructed as the difference of independent samples. Letâ€™s see how samples from Î´X(p)\delta X(p) would look like in this case!

julia> sample_X(p) = rand(Exponential(p))
sample_X (generic function with 1 method)

julia> sample_Î´X(p, Î´p) = sample_X(p + Î´p) - sample_X(p)
sample_Î´X (generic function with 1 method)

julia> p = 10; Î´p = 1e-5;

julia> sample_Î´X(p, Î´p)
-26.000938718875904

julia> sample_Î´X(p, Î´p)
-2.6157162001718092

julia> sample_Î´X(p, Î´p)
6.352622554495474

julia> sample_Î´X(p, Î´p)
-9.53215951927184

julia> sample_Î´X(p, Î´p)
1.2232268930932104

We can observe something a bit worrying: even for a very tiny Î´p\delta p (we chose Î´p=10âˆ’5\delta p = 10^{-5}), Î´X(p)\delta X(p) is still fairly large: essentially as large as the original random variables. This is not good news if we want to construct a derivative from Î´X(p)\delta X(p): we would rather see its magnitude getting smaller and smaller with Î´p\delta p, like in the non-stochastic case. Computationally, this will make it very difficult to determine $\EE[X(p)]'$ by averaging sample_Î´X(p, Î´p) / Î´p over many samples: weâ€™ll need a huge number of samples because the variance, the â€œspreadâ€ of random values, is huge for small Î´p\delta p.

Letâ€™s try a different approach. It is natural to think of X(p)X(p) for all pp as forming a family of random variables, all defined on the same probability space. A probability space, with some simplification, is a sample space Î©\Omega, with a probability distribution â„™\mathbb{P} defined on the sample space. From this point of view, each X(p)X(p) can be expressed as a function Î©â†’â„\Omega \to \mathbb{R}. To sample from a particular X(p)X(p), we can imagine drawing a random Ï‰\omega from Î©\Omega according to $\PP$, and then plugging this into X(p)X(p), i.e. computing X(p)(Ï‰)X(p)(\omega). (Computationally, this is how most distributions are actually implemented: you start with a primitive pseudo-random number generator for a very simple distribution,17 e.g. drawing values Ï‰\omega uniformly from Î©=[0,1)\Omega = [0,1), and then you build other distributions on top of this by transforming Ï‰\omega somehow.) Intuitively, all of the â€œrandomnessâ€ resides in the probability space, and crucially â„™\mathbb{P} does not depend on pp: as pp varies, X(p)X(p) just becomes a different deterministic map on Î©\Omega.

The crux here is that all the X(p)X(p) functions now depend on a shared source of randomness: the random draw of Ï‰\omega. This means that X(p)X(p) and X(p+Î´p)X(p+\delta p) have a nontrivial joint distribution: what does it look like?

For concreteness, letâ€™s study our exponential random variable X(p)âˆ¼Exp(p)X(p) \sim \operatorname{Exp}(p) from above. Using the â€œinversion samplingâ€ parameterization, it is possible to choose Î©\Omega to be [0,1)[0,1) and â„™\mathbb{P} to be the uniform distribution over Î©\Omega; for any distribution, we can construct X(p)X(p) to be a corresponding nondecreasing function over Î©\Omega (given by the inverse of X(p)X(p)â€™s cumulative probability distribution). Applied to X(p)âˆ¼Exp(p)X(p) \sim \operatorname{Exp}(p), the inversion method gives X(p)(Ï‰)=âˆ’plog(1âˆ’Ï‰)X(p)(\omega) = -p \log{(1-\omega)}. This is implemented below, and is a theoretically equivalent way of sampling X(p)X(p) compared with the opaque rand(Exponential(p)) function we used above:

julia> sample_X2(p, Ï‰) = -p * log(1 - Ï‰)
sample_X2 (generic function with 1 method)

julia> # rand() samples a uniform random number in [0,1)
julia> sample_X2(p) = sample_X2(p, rand()) 
sample_X2 (generic function with 2 methods)

julia> sample_X2(10.0)
8.380816941818618

julia> sample_X2(10.0)
2.073939134369733

julia> sample_X2(10.0)
29.94586208847568

julia> sample_X2(10.0)
23.91658360124792

Okay, so what does our joint distribution look like?

As shown in Figure 8, we can plot X(p)X(p) and X(p+Î´p)X(p+\delta p) as functions over Î©\Omega. To sample the two of them jointly, we use the same choice of Ï‰\omega: thus, Î´X(p)\delta X(p) can be formed by subtracting the two functions pointwise at each Î©\Omega. Ultimately, Î´X(p)\delta X(p) is itself a random variable over the same probability space, sampled in the same way: we pick a random Ï‰\omega according to â„™\mathbb{P}, and evaluate Î´X(p)(Ï‰)\delta X(p)(\omega), using the function Î´X(p)\delta X(p) depicted above. Our first approach with independent samples is depicted in red in Figure 8, while our second approach is in blue. We can now see the flaw of the independent-samples approach: the ğ’ª(1)\mathcal{O}(1)-sized â€œnoiseâ€ from the independent samples washes out the ğ’ª(Î´p)\mathcal{O}(\delta p)-sized â€œsignalâ€.

What about our second question (Question [question:neglect]): how can actually take the limit of Î´pâ†’0\delta p \to 0 and compute the derivative? The idea is to differentiate Î´X(p)\delta X(p) at each fixed sample Ï‰âˆˆÎ©\omega \in \Omega. In probability theory terms, we take the limit of random variables Î´X(p)/Î´p\delta X(p) / \delta p as Î´pâ†’0\delta p \to 0: Xâ€²(p)=limÎ´pâ†’0Î´X(p)Î´p.X'(p) = \lim_{\delta p \to 0} \frac{\delta X(p)}{\delta p}. For X(p)âˆ¼Exp(p)X(p) \sim \operatorname{Exp}(p) parameterized via the inversion method, we get: Xâ€²(p)(Ï‰)=limÎ´pâ†’0âˆ’Î´plog(1âˆ’Ï‰)Î´p=âˆ’log(1âˆ’Ï‰).X'(p)(\omega) = \lim_{\delta p \to 0} \frac{-\delta p\log{(1-\omega)}}{\delta p} = -\log{(1-\omega)}. Once again, Xâ€²(p)X'(p) is a random variable over the same probability space. The claim is that Xâ€²(p)X'(p) is the notion of derivative we were looking for! Indeed, Xâ€²(p)X'(p) is itself in fact a valid gradient estimator: $$\EE[X'(p)] = \EE\left[ \lim_{\delta p \to 0} \frac{\delta X(p)}{\delta p}\right] \stackrel{?}{=} \lim_{\delta p \to 0} \frac{\EE[\delta X(p)]}{\delta p} = \frac{\partial \EE[X(p)]}{\partial p}. \label{eq:exchange}$$ Rigorously, one needs to justify the interchange of limit and expectation in the above. In this chapter, however, we will be content with a crude empirical justification:

julia> Xâ€²(p, Ï‰) = -log(1 - Ï‰)
Xâ€² (generic function with 1 method)

julia> Xâ€²(p) = Xâ€²(p, rand())
Xâ€² (generic function with 2 methods)

julia> mean(Xâ€²(10.0) for i in 1:10000)
1.011689946421105

So Xâ€²(p)X'(p) does indeed average to 1, which makes sense since the expectation of Exp(p)\operatorname{Exp}(p) is pp, which has derivative 1 for any choice of pp. However, the crux is that this notion of derivative also works for more complicated random variables that can be formed via composition of simple ones such as an exponential random variable. In fact, it turns out to obey the same chain rule as usual!

Letâ€™s demonstrate this. Using the dual numbers introduced in Chapter 8, we can differentiate the expectation of the square of a sample from an exponential distribution without having an analytic expression for this quantity. (The expression for Xâ€²X' we derived is already implemented as a dual-number rule in Julia by the ForwardDiff.jl package.) The primal and dual values of the outputted dual number are samples from the joint distribution of (X(p),Xâ€²(p))(X(p), X'(p)).

julia> using Distributions, ForwardDiff: Dual

julia> sample_X(p) = rand(Exponential(p))^2
sample_X (generic function with 1 method)

julia> sample_X(Dual(10.0, 1.0)) # sample a single dual number!
Dual{Nothing}(153.74964559529033,30.749929119058066)

julia> # obtain the derivative!
julia> mean(sample_X(Dual(10.0, 1.0)).partials[1] for i in 1:10000)
40.016569793650525

Using the â€œreparameterization trickâ€ to form a gradient estimator, as we have done here, is a fairly old idea. It is also called the â€œpathwiseâ€ gradient estimator. Recently, it has become very popular in machine learning due to its use in VAEs [e.g. Kingma & Welling (2013): https://arxiv.org/abs/1312.6114], and lots of resources can be found online on it. Since composition simply works by the usual chain rule, it also works in reverse mode, and can differentiate functions far more complicated than the one above!

Handling discrete randomness

So far we have only considered a continuous random variable. Letâ€™s see how the picture changes for a discrete random variable! Letâ€™s take a simple Bernoulli variable X(p)âˆ¼Ber(p)X(p) \sim \operatorname{Ber}(p), which is 1 with probability pp and 0 with probability 1âˆ’p1-p.

julia> sample_X(p) = rand(Bernoulli(p))
sample_X (generic function with 1 method)

julia> p = 0.5
0.6

julia> sample_X(Î´p) # produces false/true, equivalent to 0/1
true


julia> sample_X(Î´p)
false

julia> sample_X(Î´p)
true

The parameterization of a Bernoulli variable is shown in Figure 2. Using the inversion method once again, the parameterization of a Bernoulli variable looks like a step function: for Ï‰<1âˆ’p\omega < 1-p, X(p)(Ï‰)=0X(p)(\omega) = 0, while for Ï‰â‰¥1âˆ’p\omega \geq 1-p, X(p)(Ï‰)=1X(p)(\omega) = 1.

Now, what happens when we perturb pp? Letâ€™s imagine perturbing pp by a positive amount Î´p\delta p. As shown in Figure 2, something qualitatively very different has happened here. At nearly every Ï‰\omega except a small region of probability Î´p\delta p, the output does not change. Thus, the quantity Xâ€²(p)X'(p) we defined in the previous subsection (which, strictly speaking, was defined by an "almost-sure" limit that neglects regions of probability 0) is 0 at every Ï‰\omega: after all, for every Ï‰\omega, there exists small enough Î´p\delta p such that Î´X(p)(Ï‰)=0\delta X(p)(\omega) = 0.

However, there is certainly an important derivative contribution to consider here. The expectation of a Bernoulli is pp, so we would expect the derivative to be 1: but $\EE[X'(p)] = \EE[0] = 0$. What has gone wrong is that, although Î´X(p)\delta X(p) is 0 with tiny probability, the value of Î´X(p)\delta X(p) on this region of tiny probability is 1, which is large. In particular, it does not approach 0 as Î´p\delta p approaches 0. Thus, to develop a notion of derivative of X(p)X(p), we need to somehow capture these large jumps with â€œinfinitesimalâ€ probability.

A recent (2022) publication (https://arxiv.org/abs/2210.08572) by the author of this chapter (Gaurav Arya), together with Frank SchÃ¤fer, Moritz Schauer, and Chris Rackauckas, worked to extend the above ideas to develop a notion of â€œstochastic derivativeâ€ for discrete randomness, implemented by a software package called StochasticAD.jl that performs automatic differentiation of such stochastic processes. It generalizes the idea of dual numbers to stochastic triples, which include a third component to capture exactly these large jumps. For example, the stochastic triple of a Bernoulli variable might look like:

julia> using StochasticAD, Distributions
julia> f(p) = rand(Bernoulli(p)) # 1 with probability p, 0 otherwise
julia> stochastic_triple(f, 0.5) # Feeds 0.5 + Î´p into f
StochasticTriple of Int64:
0 + 0Îµ + (1 with probability 2.0Îµ)

Here, Î´p\delta p is denoted by Îµ\upepsilon, imagined to be an â€œinfinitesimal unitâ€, so that the above triple indicates a flip from 0 to 1 with probability that has derivative 22.

However, many aspects of these problems are still difficult, and there are a lot of improvements awaiting future developments! If youâ€™re interested in reading more, you may be interested in the paper and our package linked above, as well as the 2020 review article by Mohamed et al. (https://arxiv.org/abs/1906.10652), which is a great survey of the field of gradient estimation in general.

At the end of class, we considered a differentiable random walk example with StochasticAD.jl. Here it is!

julia> using Distributions, StochasticAD

julia> function X(p)
           n = 0
           for i in 1:100
               n += rand(Bernoulli(p * (1 - (n+i)/200)))
           end
           return n
       end
X (generic function with 1 method)

julia> mean(X(0.5) for _ in 1:10000) # calculate E[X(p)] at p = 0.5
32.6956

julia> st = stochastic_triple(X, 0.5) # sample a single stochastic triple at p = 0.5
StochasticTriple of Int64:
32 + 0Î´p + (1 with probability 74.17635818221052Î´p)

julia> derivative_contribution(st) # derivative estimate produced by this triple
74.17635818221052

julia> # compute d/dp of E[X(p)] by taking many samples
julia> mean(derivative_contribution(stochastic_triple(f, 0.5)) for i in 1:10000)
56.65142976168479

Second Derivatives, Bilinear Maps, and Hessian Matrices

In this chapter, we apply the principles of this course to second derivatives, which are conceptually just derivatives of derivatives but turn out to have many interesting ramifications. We begin with a (probably) familiar case of scalar-valued functions from multi-variable calculus, in which the second derivative is simply a matrix called the Hessian. Subsequently, however, we will show that similar principles can be applied to more complicated input and output spaces, generalizing to a notion of fâ€³f'' as a symmetric bilinear map.

Hessian matrices of scalar-valued functions

Recall that for a function f(x)âˆˆâ„f(x) \in \mathbb{R} that maps column vectors xâˆˆâ„nx \in \mathbb{R}^n to scalars (f:â„nâ†¦â„f: \mathbb{R}^n \mapsto \mathbb{R}), the first derivative fâ€²f' can be expressed in terms of the familiar gradient âˆ‡f=(fâ€²)T\nabla f = (f')^T of multivariable calculus: âˆ‡f=(âˆ‚fâˆ‚x1âˆ‚fâˆ‚x2â‹®âˆ‚fâˆ‚xn).\nabla f = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1} \\ \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_2} \\ \vdots \\ \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_n} \end{pmatrix} \, . If we think of âˆ‡f\nabla f as a new (generally nonlinear) function mapping xâˆˆâ„nâ†¦âˆ‡fâˆˆâ„nx \in \mathbb{R}^n \mapsto \nabla f \in \mathbb{R}^n, then its derivative is an nÃ—nn \times n Jacobian matrix (a linear operator mapping vectors to vectors), which we can write down explicitly in terms of second derivatives of ff: (âˆ‡f)â€²=(âˆ‚2fâˆ‚x12â‹¯âˆ‚2fâˆ‚xnâˆ‚x1â‹®â‹±â‹®âˆ‚2fâˆ‚x1âˆ‚xnâ‹¯âˆ‚2fâˆ‚xnâˆ‚xn)=H.(\nabla f)' = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{\partial^2 f}{ \partial x_1^2} & \cdots & \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x_n \partial x_1} \\ \vdots &\ddots & \vdots \\ \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x_1 \partial x_n} & \cdots & \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x_n \partial x_n} \end{pmatrix} = H \, . This matrix, denoted here by HH, is known as the Hessian of ff, which has entries: Hi,j=âˆ‚2fâˆ‚xjâˆ‚xi=âˆ‚2fâˆ‚xiâˆ‚xj=Hj,i.H_{i,j} = \frac{\partial^2 f}{ \partial x_j \partial x_i} = \frac{\partial^2 f}{ \partial x_i \partial x_j} = H_{j,i} \, . The fact that you can take partial derivatives in either order is a familiar fact from multivariable calculus (sometimes called the â€œsymmetry of mixed derivativesâ€ or â€œequality of mixed partialsâ€), and means that the Hessian is a symmetric matrix H=HTH = H^T. (We will later see that such symmetries arise very generally from the construction of second derivatives.)

For xâˆˆâ„2x \in \mathbb{R}^2 and the function f(x)=sin(x1)+x12x23f(x) = \sin(x_1) + x_1^2 x_2^3, its gradient is âˆ‡f=(cos(x1)+2x1x233x12x22),\nabla f = \begin{pmatrix} \cos(x_1) + 2x_1 x_2^3 \\ 3 x_1^2 x_2^2 \end{pmatrix} \, , and its Hessian is H=(âˆ‡f)â€²=(âˆ’sin(x1)+2x236x1x226x1x226x12x2)=HT.H = (\nabla f)' = \begin{pmatrix} -\sin(x_1) + 2x_2^3 & 6 x_1 x_2^2 \\ 6 x_1 x_2^2 & 6 x_1^2 x_2 \end{pmatrix} = H^T \, .

If we think of the Hessian as the Jacobian of âˆ‡f\nabla f, this tells us that HdxH \, dx predicts the change in âˆ‡f\nabla f to first order: d(âˆ‡f)=âˆ‡f|x+dxâˆ’âˆ‡f|x=Hdx.d(\nabla f) = \left. \nabla f \right|_{x+dx} - \left. \nabla f \right|_{x} = H \, dx \, . Note that âˆ‡f|x+dx\left. \nabla f \right|_{x+dx} means âˆ‡f\nabla f evaluated at x+dxx+dx, which is very different from df=(âˆ‡f)Tdxdf = (\nabla f)^T dx, where we act fâ€²(x)=(âˆ‡f)Tf'(x)=(\nabla f)^T on dxdx.

Instead of thinking of HH of predicting the first-order change in âˆ‡f\nabla f, however, we can also think of it as predicting the second-order change in ff, a quadratic approximation (which could be viewed as the first three terms in a multidimensional Taylor series): f(x+Î´x)=f(x)+(âˆ‡f)TÎ´x+12Î´xTHÎ´x+o(â€–Î´xâ€–2),f(x+\delta x) = f(x) + (\nabla f)^T \, \delta x + \frac{1}{2} \delta x^T \, H \, \delta x + o(\Vert \delta x \Vert^2) \, , where both âˆ‡f\nabla f and HH are evaluated at xx, and we have switched from an infinitesimal dxdx to a finite change Î´x\delta x so that we emphasize the viewpoint of an approximation where terms higher than second-order in â€–Î´xâ€–\Vert \delta x \Vert are dropped. You can derive this in a variety of ways, e.g. by taking the derivative of both sides with respect to Î´x\delta x to reproduce âˆ‡f|x+Î´x=âˆ‡f|x+HÎ´x+o(Î´x)\left. \nabla f \right|_{x+\delta x} = \left. \nabla f \right|_{x} + H \, \delta x + o(\delta x): a quadratic approximation for ff corresponds to a linear approximation for âˆ‡f\nabla f. Related to this equation, another useful (and arguably more fundamental) relation that we can derive (and will derive much more generally below) is: dxTHdxâ€²=f(x+dx+dxâ€²)+f(x)âˆ’f(x+dx)âˆ’f(x+dxâ€²)=fâ€³(x)[dx,dxâ€²]dx^T H dx' = f(x + dx + dx') + f(x) - f(x + dx) - f(x + dx') = f''(x)[dx,dx'] \, where dxdx and dxâ€²dx' are two independent â€œinfinitesimalâ€ directions and we have dropped terms of higher than second order. This formula is very suggestive, because it uses HH to map two vectors into a scalar, which we will generalize below into the idea of a bilinear map fâ€³(x)[dx,dxâ€²]f''(x)[dx,dx']. This formula is also obviously symmetric with respect to interchange of dxdx and dxâ€²dx' â€” fâ€³(x)[dx,dxâ€²]=fâ€³(x)[dxâ€²,dx]f''(x)[dx,dx'] = f''(x)[dx',dx] â€” which will lead us once again to the symmetry H=HTH=H^T below.

Remark. Consider the Hessian matrix versus other Jacobian matrices. The Hessian matrix expresses the second derivative of a scalar-valued multivariate function, and is always square and symmetric. A Jacobian matrix, in general, expresses the first derivative of a vector-valued multivariate function, may be non-square, and is rarely symmetric. (However, the Hessian matrix is the Jacobian of the âˆ‡f\nabla f function!)

General second derivatives: Bilinear maps

Recall, as we have been doing throughout this class, that we define the derivative of a function ff by a linearization of its change dfdf for a small (â€œinfinitesimalâ€) change dxdx in the input: df=f(x+dx)âˆ’f(x)=fâ€²(x)[dx],df = f(x + dx) - f(x) = f'(x) [dx] \, , implicitly dropping higher-order terms. If we similarly consider the second derivative fâ€³f'' as simply the same process applied to fâ€²f' instead of ff, we obtain the following formula, which is easy to write down but will take some thought to interpret: dfâ€²=fâ€²(x+dxâ€²)âˆ’fâ€²(x)=fâ€³(x)[dxâ€²].d f' = f'(x + dx') - f'(x) = f''(x) [dx']. (Notation: dxâ€²dx' is not some kind of derivative of dxdx; the prime simply denotes a different arbitrary small change in xx.) What kind of â€œthingâ€ is dfâ€²df'? Letâ€™s consider a simple concrete example:

Consider the following function f(x):â„2â†¦â„2f(x): \mathbb{R}^2 \mapsto \mathbb{R}^2 mapping two-component vectors xâˆˆâ„2x \in \mathbb{R}^2 to two-component vectors f(x)âˆˆâ„2f(x) \in \mathbb{R}^2: f(x)=(x12sin(x2)5x1âˆ’x23).f(x) = \begin{pmatrix} x_1^2 \sin(x_2) \\ 5x_1 - x_2^3 \end{pmatrix} \, . Its first derivative is described by a 2Ã—22\times 2 Jacobian matrix: fâ€²(x)=(2x1sin(x2)x12cos(x2)5âˆ’3x22)f'(x) = \begin{pmatrix} 2x_1 \sin(x_2) & x_1^2 \cos(x_2) \\ 5 & -3x_2^2 \end{pmatrix} that maps a small change dxdx in the input vector xx to the corresponding small change df=fâ€²(x)dxdf = f'(x)dx in the output vector ff.

What is dfâ€²=fâ€³(x)[dxâ€²]df' = f''(x)[dx']? It must take a small change dxâ€²=(dx1â€²,dx2â€²)dx' = (dx_1', dx_2') in xx and return the first-order change dfâ€²=fâ€²(x+dxâ€²)âˆ’fâ€²(x)df' = f'(x+dx')-f'(x) in our Jacobian matrix fâ€²f'. If we simply take the differential of each entry of our Jacobian (a function from vectors xx to matrices fâ€²f'), we find: dfâ€²=(2dx1â€²sin(x2)+2x1cos(x2)dx2â€²2x1dx1â€²cos(x2)âˆ’x12sin(x2)dx2â€²0âˆ’6x2dx2â€²)=fâ€³(x)[dxâ€²]df' = \begin{pmatrix} 2\,dx_1' \sin(x_2) + 2x_1 \cos(x_2) \,dx_2' & 2 x_1 \, dx_1' \cos(x_2) - x_1^2 \sin(x_2)\, dx_2' \\ 0 & -6x_2\,dx_2' \end{pmatrix} = f''(x)[dx'] That is, dfâ€²df' is a 2Ã—22\times 2 matrix of â€œinfinitesimalâ€ entries, of the same shape as fâ€²f'.

From this viewpoint, fâ€³(x)f''(x) is a linear operator acting on vectors dxâ€²dx' and outputting 2Ã—22\times 2 matrices fâ€³(x)[dxâ€²]f''(x)[dx'], but this is one of the many cases where it is easier to write down the linear operator as a â€œruleâ€ than as a â€œthingâ€ like a matrix. The â€œthingâ€ would have to either be some kind of â€œthree-dimensional matrixâ€ or we would have to â€œvectorizeâ€ fâ€²f' into a â€œcolumn vectorâ€ of 4 entries in order to write its 4Ã—44\times 4 Jacobian, as in Sec. 3 (which can obscure the underlying structure of the problem).

Furthermore, since this dfâ€²df' is a linear operator (a matrix), we can act it on another vector dx=(dx1,dx2)dx = (dx_1, dx_2) to obtain: dfâ€²(dx1dx2)=(2sin(x2)dx1â€²dx1+2x1cos(x2)(dx2â€²dx1+dx1â€²dx2)âˆ’x12sin(x2)dx2â€²dx2âˆ’6x2dx2â€²dx2)=fâ€³(x)[dxâ€²][dx].df' \begin{pmatrix} dx_1 \\ dx_2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \sin(x_2) \,dx_1'\,dx_1 + 2x_1 \cos(x_2) (\,dx_2'\,dx_1 + \, dx_1' \, dx_2) - x_1^2 \sin(x_2)\, dx_2' \, dx_2 \\ -6x_2\,dx_2' \,dx_2 \end{pmatrix} = f''(x)[dx'][dx] \, . Notice that this result, which we will call fâ€³(x)[dxâ€²,dx]f''(x)[dx', dx] below, is the â€œsame shapeâ€ as f(x)f(x) (a 2-component vector). Moreover, it doesnâ€™t change if we swap dxdx and dxâ€²dx': fâ€³(x)[dxâ€²,dx]=fâ€³(x)[dx,dxâ€²]f''(x)[dx', dx] = f''(x)[dx, dx'], a key symmetry of the second derivative that we will discuss further below.

dfâ€²df' is an (infinitesimal) object of the same â€œshapeâ€ as fâ€²(x)f'(x), not f(x)f(x). Here, fâ€²f' is a linear operator, so its change dfâ€²df' must also be an (infinitesimal) linear operator (a â€œsmall changeâ€ in a linear operator) that we can therefore act on an arbitrary dxdx (or Î´x\delta x), in the form: dfâ€²[dx]=fâ€³(x)[dxâ€²][dx]:=fâ€³(x)[dxâ€²,dx],df'[dx] = f''(x) [dx'][dx] := f''(x) [dx', dx] \, , where we combine the two brackets for brevity. This final result fâ€³(x)[dxâ€²,dx]f''(x) [dx', dx] is the same type of object (vector) as the original output f(x)f(x). This implies that fâ€³(x)f''(x) is a bilinear map: acting on two vectors, and linear in either vector taken individually. (We will see shortly that the ordering of dxdx and dxâ€²dx' doesnâ€™t matter: fâ€³(x)[dxâ€²,dx]=fâ€³(x)[dx,dxâ€²]f''(x)[dx',dx]=f''(x)[dx,dx'].)

More precisely, we have the following.

Let U,V,WU,V,W be a vector spaces, not necessarily the same. Then, a bilinear map is a function B:UÃ—Vâ†’WB:U\times V \to W, mapping a uâˆˆUu \in U and vâˆˆVv \in V to B[u,v]âˆˆWB[u,v] \in W, such that we have linearity in both arguments: {B[u,Î±v1+Î²v2]=Î±B[u,v1]+Î²B[u,v2]B[Î±u1+Î²u2,v]=Î±B[u1,v]+Î²B[u2,v]\begin{cases} B[u, \alpha v_1 + \beta v_2] = \alpha B[u,v_1] + \beta B[u,v_2] \\ B[\alpha u_1 + \beta u_2, v] = \alpha B[u_1,v] + \beta B[u_2,v] \end{cases} for any scalars Î±,Î²\alpha, \beta,

If W=â„W = \mathbb{R}, i.e. the output is a scalar, then it is called a bilinear form.

Note that in general, even if U=VU = V (the two inputs u,vu,v are the â€œsame typeâ€ of vector) we may have B[u,v]â‰ B[v,u]B[u,v] \neq B[v,u], but in the case of fâ€³f'' we have something very special that happens. In particular, we can show that fâ€³(x)f''(x) is a symmetric bilinear map, meaning fâ€³(x)[dxâ€²,dx]=fâ€³(x)[dx,dxâ€²]f''(x) [dx', dx] = f''(x) [dx, dx'] for any dxdx and dxâ€²dx'. Why? Because, applying the definition of fâ€³f'' as giving the change in fâ€²f' from dxâ€²dx', and then the definition of fâ€²f' as giving the change in ff from dxdx, we can re-order terms to obtain: fâ€³(x)[dxâ€²,dx]=fâ€²(x+dxâ€²)[dx]âˆ’fâ€²(x)[dx]=(f(x+dxâ€²+dxâŸ=dx+dxâ€²)âˆ’f(x+dxâ€²))âˆ’(f(x+dx)âˆ’f(x))=f(x+dx+dxâ€²)+f(x)âˆ’f(x+dx)âˆ’f(x+dxâ€²)=(f(x+dx+dxâ€²)âˆ’f(x+dx))âˆ’(f(x+dxâ€²)âˆ’f(x))=fâ€²(x+dx)[dxâ€²]âˆ’fâ€²(x)[dxâ€²]=fâ€³(x)[dx,dxâ€²]\begin{aligned} f''(x) [dx', dx] &= f'(x + dx') [dx] - f'(x) [dx] \\ &= \left(f(x+ \underbrace{dx' + dx}_{= dx + dx'}) - f(x+ dx')\right) - \left(f(x+ dx) - f(x)\right) \\ &= \boxed{f(x + dx + dx') + f(x) - f(x + dx) - f(x + dx')} \\ &= \left(f(x + dx + dx') - f(x + dx)\right) - \left(f(x + dx') - f(x)\right) \\ &= f'(x + dx) [dx'] - f'(x) [dx'] \\ &= f''(x) [dx, dx'] \, \end{aligned} where weâ€™ve boxed the middle formula for fâ€³f'' which emphasizes its symmetry in a natural way. (The basic reason why this works is that the â€œ++â€ operation is always commutative for any vector space. A geometric interpretation is depicted in Fig. 12.)

Letâ€™s review the familiar example from multivariable calculus, $f: \R^n \to \R$. That is, f(x)f(x) is a scalar-valued function of a column vector $x\in \R^n$. What is fâ€³f''?

Recall that fâ€²(x)=(âˆ‡f)TâŸ¹fâ€²(x)[dx]=scalar df=(âˆ‡f)Tdx.f'(x) = (\nabla f)^T \implies f'(x) [dx] = \text{scalar } df = (\nabla f)^T dx. Similarly, fâ€³(x)[dxâ€²,dx]=scalar from two vectors, linear in both=dxâ€²THdx,\begin{aligned} f''(x) [dx', dx] &= \text{scalar from two vectors, linear in both} \\ &= dx'^T H dx \, , \end{aligned} where HH must be exactly the nÃ—nn \times n matrix Hessian matrix introduced in Sec. 12.1, since an expression like dxâ€²THdxdx'^T H dx is the most general possible bilinear form mapping two vectors to a scalar. Moreover, since we now know that fâ€³f'' is always a symmetric bilinear form, we must have: fâ€³(x)[dxâ€²,dx]=dxâ€²THdx=fâ€³(x)[dx,dxâ€²]=dxTHdxâ€²=(dxTHdxâ€²)T(scalar=scalarT)=dxâ€²THTdx\begin{aligned} f''(x) [dx', dx] &=dx'^T H dx \\ &= f''(x) [dx, dx'] = dx^T H dx' = (dx^T H dx')^T \qquad (\mathrm{scalar} = \mathrm{scalar}^T)\\ &= dx'^T H^T dx \end{aligned} for all dxdx and dxâ€²dx'. This implies that H=HTH = H^T: the Hessian matrix is symmetric. As discussed in Sec. 12.1, we already knew this from multi-variable calculus. Now, however, this â€œequality of mixed partial derivativesâ€ is simply a special case of fâ€³f'' being a symmetric bilinear map.

As an example, letâ€™s consider a special case of the general formula above:

Let f(x)=xTAxf(x) = x^T A x for $x \in \R^n$ and AA an nÃ—nn \times n matrix. As above, $f(x) \in \R$ (scalar outputs). Compute fâ€³f''.

The computation is fairly straightforward. Firstly, we have that fâ€²=(âˆ‡f)T=xT(A+AT).f' = (\nabla f)^T = x^T(A + A^T). This implies that âˆ‡f=(A+AT)x\nabla f = (A + A^T) x, a linear function of xx. Hence, the Jacobian of âˆ‡f\nabla f is the Hessian fâ€³=H=A+ATf'' = H = A + A^T. Furthermore, note that this implies f(x)=xTAx=(xTAx)T(scalar=scalarT)=xTATx=12(xTAx+xTATx)=12xT(A+AT)x=12xTHx=12fâ€³[x,x],\begin{aligned} f(x) &= x^T A x = (x^T A x)^T \qquad (\mathrm{scalar} = \mathrm{scalar}^T)\\ &= x^T A^T x \\ &= \frac{1}{2} (x^T A x + x^T A^T x) = \frac{1}{2} x^T (A + A^T) x\\ &= \frac{1}{2} x^T H x = \frac{1}{2} f''[x,x] \, , \end{aligned} which will turn out to be a special case of the quadratic approximations of Sec. 12.3 (exact in this example since f(x)=xTAxf(x)=x^T A x is quadratic to start with).

Let f(A)=detAf(A) = \det A for AA an nÃ—nn\times n matrix. Express fâ€³(A)f''(A) as a rule for fâ€³(A)[dA,dAâ€²]f''(A)[dA,dA'] in terms of dAdA and dAâ€²dA'.

From lecture 3, we have the first derivative $$f'(A) [dA] = df = \det (A) \tr(A^{-1} dA).$$ Now, we want to compute the change dâ€²(df)=dâ€²(fâ€²(A)[dA])=fâ€²(A+dAâ€²)[dA]âˆ’fâ€²(A)[dA]d'(df) = d'(f'(A)[dA]) = f'(A+dA')[dA] - f'(A)[dA] in this formula, i.e. the differential (denoted dâ€²d') where we change AA by dAâ€²dA' while treating dAdA as a constant: $$\begin{aligned} f''(A) [dA, dA'] &= d' (\det A \tr (A^{-1} dA)) \\ &= \det A \tr(A^{-1} dA') \tr(A^{-1} dA) - \det A \tr(A^{-1} \,dA' A^{-1}\, dA) \\ &= f''(A) [dA', dA] \end{aligned}$$ where the last line (symmetry) can be derived explicitly by the cyclic property of the trace (although of course it must be true for any fâ€³f''). Although fâ€³f'' here is a perfectly good bilinear form acting on matrices dA,dAâ€²dA,dA', it is not very natural to express fâ€³f'' as a â€œHessian matrix.â€

If we really wanted to express fâ€³f'' in terms of an explicit Hessian matrix, we could use the the â€œvectorizationâ€ approach of Sec. 3. Let us consider, for example, the term $\tr(A^{-1} \,dA' A^{-1}\, dA)$ using Kronecker products (Sec. 3). In general, for matrices X,Y,B,CX,Y,B,C: $$(\operatorname{vec}{X})^T (B \otimes C) \operatorname{vec}{Y} = (\operatorname{vec}{X})^T \operatorname{vec}{(CYB^T)} = \tr(X^T CYB^T) = \tr(B^T X^T CY) \, ,$$ recalling that $(\operatorname{vec}{X})^T \operatorname{vec}{Y} = \tr(X^T Y)$ is the Frobenius inner product (Sec. 5). Thus, $$\tr(A^{-1} \,dA' A^{-1}\, dA) = \operatorname{vec}{(dA'^T)}^T (A^{-T} \otimes A^{-1}) \operatorname{vec}{(dA)} \, .$$ This is still not quite in the form we want for a Hessian matrix, however, because it involves vec(dAâ€²T)\operatorname{vec}{(dA'^T)} rather than vec(dAâ€²)\operatorname{vec}{(dA')} (the two vectors are related by a permutation matrix, sometimes called a â€œcommutationâ€ matrix). Completing this calculation would be a nice exercise in mastery of Kronecker products, but getting an explicit Hessian seems like a lot of algebra for a result of dubious utility!

Generalized quadratic approximation

So how do we ultimately think about fâ€³f''? We know that fâ€²f' is the linearization/linear approximation of f(x)f(x), i.e. f(x+Î´x)=f(x)+fâ€²(x)[Î´x]+o(â€–Î´xâ€–).f(x + \delta x ) = f(x) + f'(x) [\delta x] + o(\lVert \delta x\rVert). Now, just as we did for the simple case of Hessian matrices in Sec. 12.1 above, we can use fâ€³f'' to form a quadratic approximation of f(x)f(x). In particular, one can show that f(x+Î´x)=f(x)+fâ€²(x)[Î´x]+12fâ€³(x)[Î´x,Î´x]+o(â€–Î´xâ€–2).f(x+ \delta x) = f(x) + f'(x) [\delta x] + \frac{1}{2} f''(x) [\delta x, \delta x] + o (\lVert \delta x\rVert^2). Note that the 12\frac{1}{2} factor is just as in the Taylor series. To derive this, simply plug the quadratic approximation into fâ€³(x)[dx,dxâ€²]=f(x+dx+dxâ€²)+f(x)âˆ’f(x+dx)âˆ’f(x+dxâ€²).f''(x) [dx, dx'] = f(x + dx + dx') + f(x) - f(x + dx) - f(x + dx'). and check that the right-hand side reproduces fâ€³(x)f''(x). (Note how dxdx and dxâ€²dx' appear symmetrically in this formula, which reflects the symmetry of fâ€³f''.)

Hessians and optimization

Many important applications of second derivatives, Hessians, and quadratic approximations arise in optimization: minimization (or maximization) of functions f(x)f(x).18

Newton-like methods

When searching for a local minimum (or maximum) of a complicated function f(x)f(x), a common procedure is to approximate f(x+Î´x)f(x+\delta x) by a simpler â€œmodelâ€ function for small Î´x\delta x, and then to optimize this model to obtain a potential optimization step. For example, approximating f(x+Î´x)â‰ˆf(x)+fâ€²(x)[Î´x]f(x+\delta x) \approx f(x)+f'(x)[\delta x] (an affine model, colloquially called â€œlinearâ€) leads to gradient descent and related algorithms. A better approximation for f(x+Î´x)f(x + \delta x) will often lead to faster-converging algorithms, and so a natural idea is to exploit the second derivative fâ€³f'' to make a quadratic model, as above, and accelerate optimization.

For unconstrained optimization, minimizing f(x)f(x) corresponds to finding a root of the derivative fâ€²=0f' = 0 (i.e., âˆ‡f=0\nabla f = 0), and a quadratic approximation for ff yields a first-order (affine) approximation fâ€²(x+Î´x)â‰ˆfâ€²(x)+fâ€³(x)[Î´x]f'(x + \delta x) \approx f'(x) + f''(x)[\delta x] for the derivative fâ€²f'. In â„n\mathbb{R}^n, this is Î´(âˆ‡f)â‰ˆHÎ´x\delta(\nabla f) \approx H \delta x. So, minimizing a quadratic model is effectively a Newton step Î´xâ‰ˆâˆ’Hâˆ’1âˆ‡f\delta x \approx -H^{-1} \nabla f to find a root of âˆ‡f\nabla f via first-order approximation. Thus, optimization via quadratic approximations is often viewed as a form of Newton algorithm. As discussed below, it is also common to employ approximate Hessians in optimization, resulting in â€œquasi-Newtonâ€ algorithms.

More complicated versions of this idea arise in optimization with constraints, e.g. minimizing an objective function f(x)f(x) subject to one or more nonlinear inequality constraints ck(x)â‰¤0c_k(x) \le 0. In such cases, there are a variety of methods that take both first and second derivatives into account, such as â€œsequential quadratic programmingâ€19 (SQP) algorithms that solve a sequence of â€œQPâ€ approximations involving quadratic objectives with affine constraints (see e.g. the book Numerical Optimization by Nocedal and Wright, 2006).

There are many technical details, beyond the scope of this course, that must be resolved in order to translate such high-level ideas into practical algorithms. For example, a quadratic model is only valid for small enough Î´x\delta x, so there must be some mechanism to limit the step size. One possibility is â€œbacktracking line searchâ€: take a Newton step x+Î´xx+\delta x and, if needed, progressively â€œbacktrackâ€ to x+Î´x/10,x+Î´x/100,â€¦x+\delta x/10, x+\delta x/100, \ldots until a sufficiently decreased value of the objective is found. Another commonplace idea is a â€œtrust regionâ€: optimize the model with the constraint that Î´x\delta x is sufficiently small, e.g. â€–Î´xâ€–â‰¤s\Vert \delta x \Vert \le s (a spherical trust region), along with some rules to adaptively enlarge or shrink the trust-region size (ss) depending on how well the model predicts Î´f\delta f. There are many variants of Newton/SQP-like algorithms depending on the choices made for these and other details.

Computing Hessians

In general, finding fâ€³f'' or the Hessian is often computationally expensive in higher dimensions. If $f(x): \R^n\to\R$, then the Hessian, HH, is an nÃ—nn\times n matrix, which can be huge if nn is largeâ€”even storing HH may be prohibitive, much less computing it. When using automatic differentiation (AD), Hessians are often computed by a combination of forward and reverse modes (Sec. 8.4.1), but AD does not circumvent the fundamental scaling difficulty for large nn.

Instead of computing HH explicitly, however, one can instead approximate the Hessian in various ways; in the context of optimization, approximate Hessians are found in â€œquasi-Newtonâ€ methods such as the famous â€œBFGSâ€ algorithm and its variants. One can also derive efficient methods to compute Hessianâ€“vector products HvHv without computing HH explicitly, e.g. for use in Newtonâ€“Krylov methods. (Such a product HvHv is equivalent to a directional derivative of fâ€²f', which is efficiently computed by â€œforward-over-reverseâ€ AD as in Sec. 8.4.1.)

Minima, maxima, and saddle points

Generalizing the rules you may recall from single- and multi-variable calculus, we can use the second derivative to determine whether an extremum is a minimum, maximum, or saddle point. Firstly, an extremum of a scalar function ff is a point x0x_0 such that fâ€²(x0)=0f'(x_0) = 0. That is, fâ€²(x0)[Î´x]=0f'(x_0) [\delta x] = 0 for any Î´x\delta x. Equivalently, âˆ‡f|x0=fâ€²(x0)T=0.\nabla f \bigr|_{x_0} = f'(x_0)^T = 0.

Using our quadratic approximation around x0x_0, we then have that f(x0+Î´x)=f(x0)+fâ€²(x0)[Î´x]âŸ=0+12fâ€³(x0)[Î´x,Î´x]+o(â€–Î´xâ€–2).f(x_0 + \delta x) = f(x_0) + \underbrace{f'(x_0) [\delta x]}_{=0} + \frac{1}{2} f''(x_0) [\delta x, \delta x] + o(\lVert \delta x\rVert^2). The definition of a local minimum x0x_0 is that f(x0+Î´x)>f(x0)f(x_0 + \delta x ) > f(x_0) for any Î´xâ‰ 0\delta x \neq 0 with â€–Î´xâ€–\lVert \delta x\rVert sufficiently small. To achieve this at a point where fâ€²=0f' = 0, it is enough to have fâ€³f'' be a positive-definite quadratic form: fâ€³(x0)[Î´x,Î´x]>0 for all Î´xâ‰ 0â‡”ğ©ğ¨ğ¬ğ¢ğ­ğ¢ğ¯ğ-ğğğŸğ¢ğ§ğ¢ğ­ğ fâ€³(x0).f''(x_0) [\delta x, \delta x] >0 \text{ for all } \delta x \ne 0 \iff \textbf{positive-definite } f''(x_0) \, .

For example, for inputs $x\in \R^n$, so that fâ€³f'' is a real-symmetric nÃ—nn \times n Hessian matrix, fâ€³(x0)=H(x0)=H(x0)Tf''(x_0) = H(x_0) = H(x_0)^T, this corresponds to the usual criteria for a positive-definite matrix: fâ€³(x0)[Î´x,Î´x]=Î´xTH(x0)Î´x>0 for all Î´xâ‰ 0â‡”H(x0) positive-definite â‡”all eigenvalues of H(x0)>0.f''(x_0) [\delta x, \delta x] = \delta x^T H(x_0) \delta x >0 \text{ for all } \delta x \ne 0 \iff H(x_0) \text{ positive-definite } \iff \text{all eigenvalues of } H(x_0) > 0.

In first-year calculus, one often focuses in particular on the 2-dimensional case, where HH is a 2Ã—22\times 2 matrix. In the 2Ã—22\times 2 case, there is a simple way to check the signs of the two eigenvalues of HH, in order to check whether an extremum is a minimum or maximum: the eigenvalues are both positive if and only if det(H)>0\det (H) >0 and $\tr(H) >0$, since det(H)=Î»1Î»2\det (H) = \lambda_1 \lambda_2 and $\tr(H) = \lambda_1 + \lambda_2$. In higher dimensions, however, one needs more complicated techniques to compute eigenvalues and/or check positive-definiteness, e.g. as discussed in MIT courses 18.06 (Linear Algebra) and/or 18.335 (Introduction to Numerical Methods).
